source: Charlie Munger - The Psychology of Human Misjudgment
description: Munger's 25 Standard Causes of Human Misjudgment

tendencies.name: Reward and Punishment Superresponse Tendency
tendencies.description: People respond strongly to incentives. Never think about something else when you should be thinking about the power of incentives.
examples: FedEx night shift problem solved by paying per shift not per hour
antidotes: Ask 'whose bread I eat, his song I sing'

tendencies.name: Liking/Loving Tendency
tendencies.description: We tend to ignore faults of, and comply with wishes of, those we like or love.
examples: Buying from friends even at higher prices
antidotes: Separate the person from their ideas

tendencies.name: Disliking/Hating Tendency
tendencies.description: We tend to ignore virtues of, and distort facts about, those we dislike.

tendencies.name: Doubt-Avoidance Tendency
tendencies.description: The brain is designed to remove doubt by reaching a decision quickly.

tendencies.name: Inconsistency-Avoidance Tendency
tendencies.description: We resist changing our habits, beliefs, and conclusions once formed.
examples: Refusing to update beliefs with new evidence
antidotes: Be willing to change your mind

tendencies.name: Curiosity Tendency
tendencies.description: Curiosity helps counteract other psychological tendencies.

tendencies.name: Kantian Fairness Tendency
tendencies.description: We expect fair exchanges and reciprocal behavior.

tendencies.name: Envy/Jealousy Tendency
tendencies.description: Envy is a powerful driver of irrational behavior.
antidotes: Focus on absolute not relative progress

tendencies.name: Reciprocation Tendency
tendencies.description: We feel obligated to repay favors and concessions.

tendencies.name: Influence-from-Mere-Association Tendency
tendencies.description: We are influenced by associations, even irrelevant ones.
antidotes: Look for causal not correlational links

tendencies.name: Simple Pain-Avoiding Psychological Denial
tendencies.description: We deny reality when it's too painful to accept.

tendencies.name: Excessive Self-Regard Tendency
tendencies.description: We overestimate our own abilities and worth.
examples: 90% of drivers think they're above average

tendencies.name: Over-Optimism Tendency
tendencies.description: We tend to be unrealistically optimistic about outcomes.

tendencies.name: Deprival-Superreaction Tendency
tendencies.description: We react more strongly to losses than equivalent gains.
antidotes: Frame decisions in terms of total wealth

tendencies.name: Social-Proof Tendency
tendencies.description: We look to others' behavior to determine our own.

tendencies.name: Contrast-Misreaction Tendency
tendencies.description: We judge things relative to nearby comparisons, not absolutely.
examples: Real estate showing bad houses first

tendencies.name: Stress-Influence Tendency
tendencies.description: Stress causes both enhanced and degraded performance.

tendencies.name: Availability-Misweighing Tendency
tendencies.description: We overweight information that's easily available or memorable.

tendencies.name: Use-It-or-Lose-It Tendency
tendencies.description: Skills and knowledge atrophy without practice.

tendencies.name: Drug-Misinfluence Tendency
tendencies.description: Chemical substances can dramatically alter cognition and behavior.

tendencies.name: Senescence-Misinfluence Tendency
tendencies.description: Aging naturally degrades cognitive function.

tendencies.name: Authority-Misinfluence Tendency
tendencies.description: We tend to follow authority figures even when they're wrong.

tendencies.name: Twaddle Tendency
tendencies.description: We tend to produce and consume meaningless talk.

tendencies.name: Reason-Respecting Tendency
tendencies.description: We comply more readily when given a reason, even a poor one.
examples: 'Because I need to' working in line-cutting experiments

tendencies.name: Lollapalooza Tendency
tendencies.description: Multiple psychological tendencies acting together produce extreme outcomes.
